description: From Middle English crawlen, crewlen, creulen, crallen, *cravelen, from Old Norse krafla (compare Danish kravle (“to crawl, creep”), Swedish kravla, kräla)), from Proto-Germanic *krablōną (compare Dutch krabbelen, German Low German krabbeln, German krabbeln), frequentative of *krabbōną (“to scratch, scrape”). Compare also West Frisian kreauwelje (“to crawl”), Dutch krevelen, krieuwelen (“to crawl”), German Low German kribbeln, German kribbeln (“to creep, crawl, tingle”). See also crab, crabble.

entries.meaning: The act of moving slowly on hands and knees, etc.
The act of sequentially visiting a series of similar establishments (i.e., a bar crawl).
A rapid swimming stroke with alternate overarm strokes and a fluttering kick.

examples: My computer has slowed down to a crawl since I installed that software package.

entries.meaning: (television, film) A piece of horizontally or vertically scrolling text overlaid on the main image.
examples: The opening crawl (and a stirring propaganda movie) informs us that “The Hunger Games” are an annual event in Panem, a North American nation divided into 12 different districts, each in service to the Capitol, a wealthy metropolis that owes its creature comforts to an oppressive dictatorship.

verbs.description: crawl (third-person singular simple present crawls, present participle crawling, simple past and past participle crawled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To creep; to move slowly on hands and knees, or by dragging the body along the ground.
examples: Clutching my wounded side, I crawled back to the trench.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move forward slowly, with frequent stops.
examples: The rush-hour traffic crawled around the bypass.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To act in a servile manner.
examples: Don’t come crawling to me with your useless apologies!

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Followed by with: see crawl with.

examples: The horrible sight made my skin crawl.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To swim using the crawl stroke.
examples: I think I’ll crawl the next hundred metres.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To move over (an area) on hands and knees.
examples: The baby crawled the entire second floor.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To move over (an area) slowly, with frequent stops.
(transitive, Internet) To visit files or web sites in order to index them for searching.
examples: Yahoo Search has updated its Slurp Crawler to crawl websites faster and more efficiently.

entries.meaning: A pen or enclosure of stakes and hurdles for holding fish.
